title: King Arthur wants to automate your sourdough starter
snippets: The Sourdough Sidekick is a new countertop appliance designed to automatically feed sourdough starters, ensuring they are ready for baking when needed. This product is a collaboration by FirstBuild.

title: Trump pardons ex-Nikola CEO Trevor Milton
snippets: Trevor Milton, the founder of Nikola Motors, was pardoned by President Donald Trump after being convicted of defrauding investors by lying about the capabilities of his zero-emission truck company, including claims about building its own electric truck, the Nikola One. The White House confirmed the pardon on Friday.
summary: Trevor Milton, founder of Nikola Motors, was pardoned by President Donald Trump following his conviction for defrauding investors by making false claims about his company's zero-emission trucks. The White House confirmed the pardon on Friday.

title: Google’s Pixel 9A will launch on April 10th
snippets: Google will launch the Pixel 9A in the US, Canada, and the UK on April 10th, following a delay due to a "component quality issue" after its March 19th reveal. The budget-friendly smartphone will also be released in the rest of Europe at a later date.
summary: Google is set to release the Pixel 9A in the US, Canada, and the UK on April 10th, after a delay related to a "component quality issue" post its March 19th reveal. The budget smartphone will launch in the rest of Europe later.

title: NASA and Boeing investigate Starliner’s ‘anomalies’ before its next crewed flight

title: Helldivers 2 is locking out players who use older CPUs

title: Yale’s new smart lock can match your Google Nest doorbell

This announcement comes after Google decided to discontinue its Nest x Yale Lock.

title: A genetic tree as a movie: Moving beyond the still portrait of ancestry
snippets: Researchers have developed a statistical method that visualizes the migration of ancestors across the globe over time, transforming traditional family trees into dynamic movies. This innovative approach can also be applied to study the spread of diseases and track animal movements across different regions.
summary: Researchers have created a new statistical method that turns the migration patterns of ancestors into dynamic visual movies, rather than static family trees. This method not only helps in understanding human ancestral movements but is also useful in tracking the spread of diseases and animal migration across various regions.

title: Melting ice, more rain drive Southern Ocean cooling
snippets: Researchers have discovered that 60% of the discrepancy between expected and actual ocean temperatures around Antarctica over several decades can be attributed to increased meltwater and rainfall in the region.
summary: Researchers found that 60% of the difference in predicted vs. actual ocean temperatures near Antarctica over many years is due to more meltwater and rainfall in that area.

title: Cartilage and bone development: Three paths to skeleton formation
snippets: Researchers have found that in vertebrates, skeletal cells from different body regions originate from various precursor cells and have distinct gene regulation. This discovery highlights a potential factor in the evolutionary success of vertebrates.
summary: Researchers discovered that vertebrates' skeletal cells come from different precursor cells in various body regions, each with unique gene regulation. This diversity may contribute to vertebrates' evolutionary success.

title: Terahertz imaging: Breakthrough in non-invasive cochlear visualization
snippets: Researchers have developed a new non-invasive method using terahertz (THz) imaging to create high-resolution, 3D visualizations of cochlear structures in mice. This advancement may improve diagnostics for hearing loss and other conditions, potentially leading to the creation of miniaturized THz diagnostic devices. This technology promises to enhance diagnostic accuracy, speed, and patient outcomes in various medical fields.
summary: Researchers have developed a non-invasive technique using terahertz imaging to produce detailed 3D images of cochlear structures in mice. This method could enhance diagnostics for hearing loss and other conditions, potentially leading to smaller diagnostic devices. The technology aims to improve diagnostic precision, speed, and patient outcomes across multiple medical areas.

title: We must not ignore eugenics in our genetics curriculum, says professor

summary: Mark Peifer, a biology professor at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, promotes adding eugenics to college genetics curriculums. He argues this will aid scientists in combating the misuse of science for political reasons by motivating them to voice their concerns.
